docs.title: 5ttgen
docs.description:
Generate a 5TT image suitable for ACT.

5ttgen acts as a 'master' script for generating a five-tissue-type (5TT) segmented tissue image suitable for use in Anatomically-Constrained Tractography (ACT). A range of different algorithms are available for completing this task. When using this script, the name of the algorithm to be used must appear as the first argument on the command-line after '5ttgen'. The subsequent compulsory arguments and options available depend on the particular algorithm being invoked.
Each algorithm available also has its own help page, including necessary references; e.g. to see the help page of the 'fsl' algorithm, type '5ttgen fsl'.

docs.title: algorithm
docs.description: Select the algorithm to be used to complete the script operation; additional details and options become available once an algorithm is nominated. Options are: freesurfer, fsl, gif, hsvs

docs.title: output
docs.description: The output 5TT image

docs.title: freesurfer
docs.description: Generate the 5TT image based on a FreeSurfer parcellation image

docs.title: input
docs.description: The input FreeSurfer parcellation image (any image containing 'aseg' in its name)

docs.title: output
docs.description: The output 5TT image

docs.title: lut
docs.description: Manually provide path to the lookup table on which the input parcellation image is based (e.g. FreeSurferColorLUT.txt)

docs.title: freesurfer
docs.description: Generate the 5TT image based on a FreeSurfer parcellation image

docs.title: output
docs.description: The output 5TT image

docs.title: fsl
docs.description: Use FSL commands to generate the 5TT image based on a T1-weighted image

docs.title: input
docs.description: The input T1-weighted image

docs.title: output
docs.description: The output 5TT image

docs.title: t2
docs.description: Provide a T2-weighted image in addition to the default T1-weighted image; this will be used as a second input to FSL FAST

docs.title: mask
docs.description: Manually provide a brain mask, rather than deriving one in the script

docs.title: premasked
docs.description: Indicate that brain masking has already been applied to the input image

docs.title: fsl
docs.description: Use FSL commands to generate the 5TT image based on a T1-weighted image

docs.title: output
docs.description: The output 5TT image

docs.title: gif
docs.description: Generate the 5TT image based on a Geodesic Information Flow (GIF) segmentation image

docs.title: input
docs.description: The input Geodesic Information Flow (GIF) segmentation image

docs.title: output
docs.description: The output 5TT image

docs.title: gif
docs.description: Generate the 5TT image based on a Geodesic Information Flow (GIF) segmentation image

docs.title: output
docs.description: The output 5TT image

docs.title: hsvs
docs.description: Generate a 5TT image based on Hybrid Surface and Volume Segmentation (HSVS), using FreeSurfer and FSL tools

docs.title: input
docs.description: The input FreeSurfer subject directory

docs.title: output
docs.description: The output 5TT image

docs.title: template
docs.description: Provide an image that will form the template for the generated 5TT image

docs.title: hippocampi
docs.description: Select method to be used for hippocampi (& amygdalae) segmentation; options are: subfields,first,aseg

docs.title: thalami
docs.description: Select method to be used for thalamic segmentation; options are: nuclei,first,aseg

docs.title: white_stem
docs.description: Classify the brainstem as white matter

docs.title: hsvs
docs.description: Generate a 5TT image based on Hybrid Surface and Volume Segmentation (HSVS), using FreeSurfer and FSL tools

docs.title: nocrop
docs.description: Do NOT crop the resulting 5TT image to reduce its size (keep the same dimensions as the input image)

docs.title: sgm_amyg_hipp
docs.description: Represent the amygdalae and hippocampi as sub-cortical grey matter in the 5TT image

docs.title: nocleanup
docs.description: do not delete intermediate files during script execution, and do not delete scratch directory at script completion.

docs.title: scratch
docs.description: manually specify the path in which to generate the scratch directory.

docs.title: continue
docs.description: continue the script from a previous execution; must provide the scratch directory path, and the name of the last successfully-generated file.

docs.title: info
docs.description: display information messages.

docs.title: quiet
docs.description: do not display information messages or progress status; alternatively, this can be achieved by setting the MRTRIX_QUIET environment variable to a non-empty string.

docs.title: debug
docs.description: display debugging messages.

docs.title: force
docs.description: force overwrite of output files (caution: using the same file as input and output might cause unexpected behaviour).

docs.title: nthreads
docs.description: use this number of threads in multi-threaded applications (set to 0 to disable multi-threading).

docs.title: config
docs.description: temporarily set the value of an MRtrix config file entry.

docs.title: key
docs.description: temporarily set the value of an MRtrix config file entry.

docs.title: value
docs.description: temporarily set the value of an MRtrix config file entry.

docs.title: config
docs.description: temporarily set the value of an MRtrix config file entry.

docs.title: help
docs.description: display this information page and exit.

docs.title: version
docs.description: display version information and exit.

docs.title: 5ttgen
docs.description:
Generate a 5TT image suitable for ACT.

5ttgen acts as a 'master' script for generating a five-tissue-type (5TT) segmented tissue image suitable for use in Anatomically-Constrained Tractography (ACT). A range of different algorithms are available for completing this task. When using this script, the name of the algorithm to be used must appear as the first argument on the command-line after '5ttgen'. The subsequent compulsory arguments and options available depend on the particular algorithm being invoked.
Each algorithm available also has its own help page, including necessary references; e.g. to see the help page of the 'fsl' algorithm, type '5ttgen fsl'.
